title: Many problems
body: 2 receptionists are good, 2 nurses are great. Hardly see a doctor usually clinical pharmacist. Main doctor sold practice to bardoc he said the practice is run very badly and to report it. Doctors tell you the very worst scenario before you've even had any tests and put fear in you causing terrible anxiety. Can't get through at 8am and by 9am appointments have all gone, reception say try tomorrow or next day, this is extremely stressful especially for senior citizens. One receptionist was very rude when asked for some paperwork from the hospital yet it was the doctor who told me to ask for it. Only one lady doctor whose very blunt no warmth. Receptionists don't know who some of the doctors are as too many locums. Was kept waiting 45 minutes past appointment time once causing anxiety. Some newer doctors make you feel uncomfortable and are blunt leaving you upset and anxious. Tests get lost or discarded and have to be repeated. Once the toilet was too filthy to use.

title: Not a great practice
body: I waited on the telephone for an hour, hoping to schedule an appointment. Unfortunately, due to my month-long illness, I had to visit the walk-in center instead. The difficulty in getting through to someone was frustrating, and when I finally did, I was directed to contact another number or return to the walk-in center. The quality of service has been quite disappointing.

title: Poor signage
body: Signage very poor. Had to ask where clinic was twice, had to go through a doorway then found the clinic.  There are no way out signs or easily visible. A male patient had to ask how to get out of the building. I have heard many people say this. The manager needs to review the whole building with a view to first time visiting patients

author: Wittleeeyore
title: Trying to get a autism referral for my daughter.
body:
Trying to get a autism referral for my child I went to the GP as stated on NHS website. The GP said I needed to get a report from the school myself and refer them to cheviot youth. I done this and the school nurse also went into the school. Even with the school report and a questionnaire I had done and all my concerns they decided that it was not enough and asked me to do even more.  
No support no nothing. I spoke to the occupational therapy team and they do not understand why I've to do a self referral. Whilst all this is going on there is no support for my child and they do not see the point in trying to get help as nobody seems interested. The doctor never spoke to them at the initial appointment. The only person who has spoke to them has been the school nurse. My child appears to be very good at masking their true self while they are at school and my concern now is that nobody seems to be interested in helping but they are quite willing to let a child suffer. Appalling service received

title: Great practice
body:
I cannot praise each nurse, GP and receptionist enough at the wall house.
Each time I need to be seen I have been given an appointment, and also each professional I have dealt with has been caring and kind and taken time to listen to me,which I need at the moment with all I am going through, just couldn't ask to be with a better surgery than this one, I am so grateful to be a patient at the wall house , and I cannot give praise enough, thankyou all .

author: Mental Health Nurse
title: My first C-section experience
body:
I had a planned c section in June at the maternity department Victoria hospital. I was then an inpatient until the Friday.  
From the moment I entered the ward I was considerably anxious, I met the two anesthetists (I cannot remember their names) who were so understanding and supportive explaining how I would feel when the medications were administered. The Dr Clark then visited me who again was so understanding and patient centred and she explained everything.  
I was lucky enough to have the most reassuring and calming midwife in Leanne young who would go on to make my whole experience a positive one.  
Unfortunately I lost 1.8 litres of blood and spend around 8 hours in recovery. My experience of recovery was again a positive one with the staff being helpful, and thorough with my care while encouraging the bonding with my daughter. I was looked after by Jennifer , student midwife, who you would never guess was spending her first day of placement on a hospital ward. She was professional, passionate and had excellent communication skills. The staff that looked after me were Leanne, Sarah , Emma and Nikki who were all equally good at their jobs and nothing was too much trouble, From answering my questions to assisting me to get back on my feet after surgery all while having smile on their faces.  
I was taken to the ward around 10:00pm and instantly welcomed by Eliza who would go on to be my nightshift midwife that I would be supported by for the next three nights.  
Over my 4 day stay I was supported and looked after by Chantelle, Lana , Claire and Sarah who all provided excellent patient care, supporting me to breastfeed and reassuring me when things were tough. It was clear to see that they enjoyed their jobs and treated all patients with not only dignity and respect but also individualised care and treatment.  
Dr Clark visited me on the ward prior to discharge and she was amazing, understanding and showed care and compassion.  
My first C-section experience was a positive one thanks to the staff and their standard of care.  
Thank you from us all

author: Member67
title: Looked after as both a patient and family.
body:
My husband was admitted to have his appendix removed, initially attending the OOH GP service then being admitted to SAU, Ward 57 and finally Ward 24. We just wanted to say a thank you to everyone involved. The whole process was as seamless as possible and every staff member we encountered was friendly, helpful and completely professional despite clearly being incredibly busy. Nothing ever appeared a bother.  
Particular mention should go to a staff nurse named Keira on ward 24 who was so kind and reassuring during a late night phonecall to myself when things were taking longer than expected in theatre. It really meant a lot.  
We’re from a medical background and completely appreciate the pressures the nhs is currently under- it felt strange being on the other side but we felt so well looked after as both a patient and family.  
I hope this message is passed onto all the mentioned teams and many thanks again.

readBy.name: Office of Foysol Choudhury, MSP for North Edinburgh, Leith, Edinburgh Western & West Lothian

author: sagittary33
title: Reassured that I was in the right hands going forward.
body:
After a recent massive heart attack I was referred to Shileen and Jayne in the Cardiac Rehabilitation service at Mullinure Hospital Armagh. Not knowing what to expect both ladies were very caring and professional and took time to explain to me the effects of what happened and the plan going forward.  
I could not have been more reassured when listening to them that I was in the right hands going forward.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: SME2019
title: Friendly radiography service
body: I had an ultrasound of my liver following cholestasis during pregnancy. I was taken on time for my appointment with a very friendly radiographer who made pleasant chit chat during the scan. Made me feel at ease during the appointment and the scan was done swiftly and efficiently.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Grateful retired doctor
title: My retinal tear
body:
I developed an eye problem at the end of a holiday in Greece. I decided to wait until I returned home as I was reluctant to contact the Greek health services.  
On return home I rang 111. I spoke to someone who asked appropriate questions. Within half an hour I was rung by a doctor who offered an Out of Hours GP appointment within 45 minutes. I was duly seen and the doctor phoned the on call ophthalmologist who said that I should be the following morning in the Eye Clinic.  
I was phoned by the Eye Clinic next morning at 8:00am and offered an appointment at 9:00am. I was then seen by an eye specialist, who said that I had a retinal tear and it would need laser treatment that day. This was then done within the hour - what brilliant service, preventing more of a problem. I have since been reviewed and am making good progress.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: David545
title: Excellent Care
body: I returned from a trip to the USA with a swollen and painful leg. I thought it might be a deep vein thrombosis. I contacted my GP who invited me to come to the surgery right away. She examined me and gave me an anti-coagulant injection. She then made an appointment for me to go to hospital to check whether it was a DVT. I arrived at hospital. People were very friendly and I was in and out in a reasonably short period of time. The whole process was excellent and the staff all round were first class. Very impressive.

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership

author: GratefulFamily342
title: My father and the amazing perfect care they gave him
body: My father has been treated at the Victoria Hospital in Kirkcaldy on and off for the past 3 years. 8 weeks and 1 day ago he was admitted to ward 53 for palliative care in what would be his final visit to the hospital. We just want to thank all the day and night staff for the most perfect, considerate and care they gave him and us for the past 2 months. Their care has been exactly that, truly caring in every way, every member of staff has been outstanding and they went above and beyond every day, in every way possible to each one of us, and as a large traveller family we want to thank them from the bottom of our hearts for making these final weeks that little bit easier, and for not giving up on him whenever there was the smallest glimmer of help. We will be forever grateful to you.

title: Absolutely amazing
body:
After being dealt with by 111 so brilliantly I was whisked into A&E, which was packed out on a Sunday but they were amazing. I was sorted in about an hour and immediately taken to get my Eye sorted. 

I cannot praise the Eye Clinic enough though. I've been with them twice now and each time they've been nothing short of amazing. I was cared for beautifully on the Sunday and my check up on the following Friday was speedy and thorough. Everyone was so kind and friendly despite it being busy. Thank you so so much for looking after me.

author: last08042821
title: Childhood asthma
body:
My child has struggled with respiratory illness most of their life. With multiple visits to ED and our GP for antibiotics, steroids, inhalers etc. My child has been given inhalers for asthma with no guidance on how to use these or review in place for a check up from their GP or respiratory clinic. When approached recently by their school for a care plan our GP refused to give this as my child didn’t have asthma. Nobody can tell me why my child has been given all this medication and treatment when they apparently do not have the condition. I was advised a referral had been done for paediatric outpatients for an asthma review however, when I contacted my (new) GP for something else months later, they could tell me no referral had been done. They then completed this while I waited but this added to our wait time for an appt, all the time my child was still struggling with respiratory issues.  
My child has recently attended the paediatrician, who cannot understand why they have been given the medicines involved for treatment of asthma without any form of investigation, no peak flow readings, no physical examination just handed a prescription from a phone consultation.  
I’ve tried to get in touch with the practice manager to discuss this issue to no avail, they seem to avoid my calls, cancelled appointments to chat and has ignored any correspondence so this is my last attempt to get an answer, as my child is being severely let down by lack of care/compassion from this practice.

author: gifted79
title: I would wholeheartedly recommend this place
body:
I felt really comfortable as soon as I walked in. The staff have all been brilliant, they are all really caring and reliable. I was on a heroin and crack before I came in and was worried about cravings and withdrawals but after the first 2 days had no problems. My detox went perfect. The food here is amazing- I have put 5 kilograms on since coming here.  
I would wholeheartedly recommend this place to anyone who is truly looking to be addiction free.

author: Heart racing
title: Excellent treatment in A&E following fracture
body:
I fell from my horse last week. I knew immediately I had hurt my shoulder. I was in agony - the worst pain I’ve ever experienced. The waiting room was packed, but the receptionist realised I was in severe pain. She directed my husband where to go for help. Staff came to me really quickly.  
There were a couple of nurses, I think, and an amazing doctor called Zoe. They were amazingly professional. Made quick clinical judgement and got me amazing pain relief.  
I don’t remember going to X-ray or coming back. It was all very quick and efficient. I was diagnosed with a fractured clavicle, put in a sling, given pain relief and advised re follow up in just over an hour. Absolutely incredible, appropriate management in an extremely busy, pressurised environment for staff.  
Can’t thank them enough for the care they gave me

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: zebraqw39
title: Kind nursing staff.
body:
Rocked in this morning with for endoscopy. Full of fear and uncertainty. The Staff were absolutely amazing: from Retty to Bronagh and her team, Tes and the consultant.
It's nothing like having someone smiling at you and encouraging you on a journey like this.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: GEMB71
title: Out of Hours Care
body:
I had to use NHS24 for an elderly relative. In short the turn around from initial call with waiting times to OOHs phoning then obtaining a prescription was 4 hours. On a Sunday afternoon. I was impressed.  
Given the current situation the NHS is in just now it is clear people and services are pushing on with patient care. From the Call Handler (Mark), to the Nurse (Elaine) to the male GP who called from Stirling OOHs they were all pleasant, professional and caring. Thanks

author: zulufp68
title: Thank you from the bottom of my heart you were all faultless.
body:
On Thursday my little girl had an accident with her trampoline and broke her arm, we rushed to Bassetlaw hospital where even though A&E was very busy they saw to her in exceptional time, and she was quickly sent to X-ray to confirm that it was indeed broken. They went above and beyond to make sure she was comfortable and was seen to quickly.  
Friday we then had to go to DRI where again she was looked after so well, in both theatre and children’s observation unit. A big thank you to Bobbie and all the team on the unit that made sure she was ok. I couldn’t fault both hospitals as they were great with her and made it so easy. Thank you from the bottom of my heart you were all faultless.

readBy.name: Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Kacey
title: The birth of my daughter
body:
At the start of June I was 39 weeks pregnant and my waters broke. I attended the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital and gave birth via Caesarean Section later that night. During my stay at the hospital, several of the staff were outstanding in terms of their care and holistic approach.  
Rachel (Staff Midwife) looked after me on the antenatal ward. She was very attentive and regularly checked in to ensure my baby, myself and my partner were safe and well. She regularly kept us updated and did everything she could to support me in the early stages of labour.  
Later that night, I was taken to labour ward for an unplanned C Section. The theatre team were outstanding - I felt safe and supported throughout the procedure. Everyone did their best to put both myself and my partner at ease and kept us informed at every stage. The team were professional, efficient and person centred to my needs. We felt in very safe hands and everyone in the theatre worked well as a team.  
Louise (Staff Midwife) looked after me and my baby on the postnatal ward and she was an amazing support. She provided excellent support and care in my recovery from the caesarean and was there whenever I needed support with my health needs or caring for my baby.  
I would like all of the health care practitioners mentioned above to know that I appreciated their care and support and to thank them for everything they did for my baby, myself and my partner.

author: Mental Health Nurse
title: Excellent midwife
body:
I was booked in for an elective c section in June at Victoria hospital.  
I was very very anxious about the surgery and for the majority of my pregnancy. We were shown to a bay and some tests were carried out, i then met the midwife Leanne who was responsible for all elective c sections.  
Leanne introduced herself to me my partner and my mum, she explained what would be happening and when. Leanne reassured me and explained that she would be there the whole way through and after.  
During surgery I lost a lot of blood and she explained that I would need to go to recovery to be monitored but it was nothing to worry about.  
She was helpful and answered any questions that me and my mum had throughout the operation.  
When I was taken to recovery Leanne helped look after me and she made sure I was able to see my son also, as she knew how important it was to me.  
When Leanne came on shift the following day she checked in on me and my baby, and did so until I was discharged on the Friday.  
Leanne really made my whole experience enjoyable and did her best to alleviate my anxieties through my stay.  
If only all midwife’s could be like Leanne, she was professional but open and honest and it was clear to see that she is extremely passionate about being a midwife and providing the best care to women and there babies while making partners/ birthing partners part of the experience.  
Leanne has excellent communication and interpersonal skills and I felt like my opinion mattered throughout the whole process, she practices in s very patient centred way.  
I value having Leanne as my midwife and sharing a part of my baby’s journey.

author: s-ferg
title: Community Paediatric Service
body:
My son has ASD and global development delay, likely ADHD and we are on the waiting list for neurodevelopmental services for formal diagnosis. We saw the Community Paediatrician in Dec 2022 for a very helpful appointment, the first time we have interacted with a doctor since my son was discharged from the neonatal clinic in 2020. The doctor took all the history, we discussed my son's issues and they prescribed melatonin as well as referring us for a range of genetic tests.  
Since then my interaction with the service e.g. to discuss dosage, follow up from blood tests etc has been incredibly poor. The secretaries are helpful and do their best in difficult circumstances but a number of doctors are on long term sick leave (and I wish them well, my frustration is not at them personally). There seems to be nothing in place for cases to be picked up by other members of the medical team.  
My son had blood tests at the beginning of May and I cannot find out the results. This was to do with low platelets and I want to know if there is still an issue. I only managed to speak to another Consultant around my son's sleep deterioration and get increased dosage prescribed following multiple emails, phone calls, contact with the Child Health Commissioner. There is no service.  
Parenting a child with additional support needs is difficult enough exacerbated by the constant fight for support. It is draining and exhausting and I don't believe other health conditions would be treated in this way. The lack of investment in services, the lack of follow up and care leads me to the conclusion that we live in a society where ultimately disabled children's lives are not valued and families are just left to struggle. It doesn't need to be like this.  
I understand the workforce issues and the demand on services but there needs to be a more holistic approach to supporting autistic children. We get help from speech and language and I recently attended an occupational therapy workshop but there needs to be one person who is wholly responsible for my son's care who is overseeing everything and able to provide advice and support. Instead I tell our story over and over again to different professionals. Nothing is joined up. I'll begin the calls and emails again tomorrow morning looking for my son's results.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership
Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists (RCSLT)

author: pyxisqx63
title: Excellent service
body:
Last week I attended the Grampian Sexual Health Service for a routine contraceptive procedure and I wanted to highlight the excellent care I received from Dr Cook and Healthcare Support Worker, Ugo, whilst in clinic.  
As a nervous patient, I was anxious about the procedure, however both team members immediately put me at ease with their welcoming and professional approach.  
Dr Cook took the time to discuss the procedure with me, answer my questions and provide advice. Ugo helped to calm my nerves and provided support not only to Dr Cook, but to me also.  
Both team members provided excellent care throughout my visit to the clinic and are an asset to the service. First class care was received - thank you.

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Emmgh49
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Cheerful staff
body: I arrived to hospital on Thursday and went to the emergency department, I was there at 2:15 received a few blood tests and didn't get seen by a doctor until 4. I was placed on a chair until I got a bed and then when I arrived to the ward there wasn't any space either so I got moved around a good bit. I'm currently on an extra bed in the double side room, it isn't too bad I'm glad I have a bed to rest in. The care I have been receiving has been great the staff are all very cheerful and happy.  The communication hasn't been great there has been a few mix ups, I was told I was getting a scan, then a few hours later I was told by another doctor I was getting sent home and he was unaware of the scan. So I think this could be improved, if they were clearer with each other about what was going on these things wouldn't happen. The food has been acceptable, its not the best but its fine. The wards very clean and the facilities have all been good.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Rooroo
title: Person Centred Care
body:
I was admitted to hospital writhing in agony after a flare up of gallstones. I was taken to the surgical assessment unit who dealt with my pain immediately and started tests all the while reassuring me and asking how my pain level was. From there I went to Surgical ward B3 where I spent the next 5 days on IV antibiotics and sleeping a lot. Each day the nurses would come in , do my obs, top up water, fetch towels etc. as well as having a wee chat. The consultants discussed what my plan was and made me feel I was part of this discussion, not just a patient being told what was happening.  
They decided that an operation would be required so I was taken to theatre by one of the nurses and a porter who chatted away the whole time with me. I was greeted by the theatre staff and had a wee chat with them too about the procedure.  
Operation done and back to the ward with another couple of porters chatting away and asking me the odd question which I was quite oblivious to due to the anaesthetic. So here I am hoping to get home tomorrow reflecting on my patient experience.  
What I realised this week was when we use the words person centred care, I know exactly what that means as I was at the heart of everything and felt the compassion, caring, kind, professional, quality of care, as well as listening ears and good humour of all the staff.  
My care and support have been second to none and I couldn't thank enough, all the staff I came in contact with for making me well again.

author: nm11
title: Very poor service from GP out of hours
body:
I called Western Urgent Care at 09:30, got quickly through to telephone centre who took my details. A triage nurse called me at 13:00 and advised they would send my case to the GP for a prescription. I am 28 weeks pregnant and have had a productive cough for a few weeks which has worsened over the weekend and leaving me short of breath and exhausted.  
It is 22:45 and I still haven’t received a prescription or call from the doctor. I have called frequently to the telephone centre who are trying to help but there is nothing they can do. It’s is terrifying how bad this service is, especially in July.  
I really fear for the winter if the GPOOH services cope this badly in summer.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

author: Ajaybee
title: Care in Victoria Hospital, Kirkcaldy (NHS Fife)
body:
I have had 3 hospital stays at Victoria Hospital, Kirkcaldy during June 2023. Having been admitted via the Urgent Care Service and subsequently moved onto Ward 52 I was cared for by various members of staff, all of whom provided very high levels and standards of care hampered more often than not only by the lack of access to diagnostic equipment (in my case an MRI scan). I met Dr Gregory whilst on the Ward and I was immediately impressed by his openness, friendliness and informality. He explained in depth the issues I was experiencing and the next steps to be taken. He alone is the best possible advertisement for great care in the NHS.  
I was recalled for a procedure in the Day Intervention Unit 2 weeks later, where my named nurse, Courtney could not have offered a higher standard of care. She simply did everything that I requested or needed with charm and sensitivity and took the time to listen to my concerns and deal with them. She and the other members of the nursing team in the Unit worked hard to keep the constant flow of patients in and out well managed. They all did this with a genuine desire to care for every one. I also met Dr John at this time, who in a similar vein to Dr Ekatah is the most charming, open and caring person. He very much put my mind at rest over any doubts I had concerning my procedure.  
A week later I was called in for the final operation. On my arrival Dr Ekatah was waiting for me in the Day Surgery Unit. He further explained the whole procedure and thoroughly detailed the risks and negatives as well as the benefits. He very much, as previously made me feel more confident and relaxed about the operation. My named nurse, responsible for my care that day was Keren. I had met her a week earlier in the Day Intervention Unit where she had been helping out and she immediately recognised me. Keren is another fine example of an interested, caring nurse. She manages to juggle several tasks at once and always takes time to understand the patient's needs. She has boundless energy, operating at full steam right up until her shift ends. She represents everything that is great about the NHS and never shows any sign of discontent. She's simply first class. After Keren's shift ended my named nurse was Andy. I've yet to meet another person like Andy, who does everything with such precision and in an unruffled manner. If I had any concerns following my operation Andy, simply by his presence would have put my mind at rest. He's such an easy going yet incredibly effective nurse and sums up what great quality care is.  
Every health care professional I met during my stays in June from junior nurses through to anaesthetists, theatre staff and consultants was caring, fastidious in the way they function and extremely effective in making my stay more comfortable.  
The people more than any other aspect of my experiences made them acceptable. The hospital itself is very comfortable, clean as far as I can tell and well equipped. It simply has insufficient resources to deal with the heavy demand on the services. The staff very efficiently smooth out any deficiencies so that patient care, where possible doesn't suffer.  
I thank all of the Fife NHS staff I encountered, and a special thank you goes to those I have named. Without every one of you I would not be as happy and well as I now am. Thank you one and all.

readBy.name: Office of Annabelle Ewing, MSP for Cowdenbeath

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: PAW is thorough
body:
PAW is clean. The environment is great and everything that is a danger to a child is put at a height, thought was put behind it. I cannot believe how nice it is here as I have never been here. I have had to bring my children in when it was wards for children however, I am bringing my grandchild in and it has improved massively.  
The staff are also amazing, they really are. I cannot believe how much they seem to genuinely care about my grandchild. Also, they are have a smile on their faces all the time.  
PAW is thorough.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: homamey56
title: Treated with respect and kindness
body:
I have suffered from chronic uveitis for many years and cataracts in recent years. I regularly attend the eye clinic at Treliske Hospital in Truro. I have always been treated with respect and kindness and the staff are very helpful. On occasions I need to call them for an emergency appointment due to a flareup of uveitis and am always seen very promptly.  
Over recent years I have developed cataracts. I have had one eye operated on, it's fantastic I can now see clearly and appreciate the brightness of colours! After a routine appointment about my uveitis with the lovely Louisa, Clinical Nurse Specialist (who has a lovely sense of humor and nothing is too much trouble for her) is arranging for my other cataract to be operated on.  
While I would like to say thank you to all the staff in the eye clinic, I would like to also like to say a huge and heartfelt thank you to Louise , Clinical Nurse Specialist; Mr Partwardhan, my Consultant for many years and Mr Ali, Associate Specialist Ophthalmologist, who carried out my cataract operation.

author: Emmgh49
title: The ward is perfect I'm very comfortable
body: I arrived to the ward last Tuesday and was quickly given a bed everything was very straightforward. I'm very happy with the care the staff have provided to me after my surgery. I have been getting good updates from staff on the ward . The wards perfect I'm very comfortable and everything on the ward is kept very clean. The only problem or improvement that would need to be made is with the meals , it hasn't been very nice and after being in here for nearly a week you get very sick of it.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: magpiezf85
title: Fantastic Nurse gave me result of DXA scan
body:
Nurse Karen at Victoria Hospital in Kirkaldy Fracture Liaison Service gave me results of DXA scan which my GP did not, and told me I had osteoporosis in a very gentle way, explaining the possible treatment I would be given. She was incredibly reassuring and factual and prevented me from being extremely worried.  
I had to suggest the scan myself BEFORE breaking my shoulder and wrist and the nursing staff were very supportive. Karen's help has been invaluable. It's quite a diagnosis. It's affected my Mother terribly.

author: Niamhh1
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: I have had a grand stay
body: The staff have been so pleasant and comforting. I am grateful for their compassion and care. I am happy with my room I think its very big and bright. The food has been lovely, the variety is lacking, as its so warm I wouldn't tend to order soups or hot meals for lunch and dinner however the only real alternative is a salad. The communication with the staff has been top notch, facilities are all fine and everything is very accessible. I have had a fairly grand stay.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamhh1
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Excellent staff
body:
The staff on the ward have been excellent, I couldn't complain about the care at all, its great. The food is poor, I am not a big eater anyway, I will usually just have wee small things throughout the day, i just think the big portions at lunch and dinner are just too much.  
Communication has been good, the staff are very caring and are always doing a lot for you. The cleanliness is perfect, couldn't fault the cleaning staff.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamhh1
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Lovely nurses
body:
The care I have received in gynae has been second to none. The lovely nurses just do a wonderful job. The food is decent.  
Communication with staff has been really good, everyone has been lovely and have listened to me, staff are also happy enough answering questions.  
Overall, a good stay and no problems.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Emmgh49
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Provided great care
body: I have been on this ward for one week, I waited a few hours when I arrived to hospital but nothing to long. The ward is fine, I have been able to use all the facilities okay they are all accessible and kept clean. The nurses and care assistants have made me feel comfortable and have provided great care, I couldn't  complain as they  work extremely hard and have did a lot for me. The food has been fine, the menu is big so there is a lot of choices.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Emmgh49
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: they should just keep up the good work!
body: I was brought to emergency department when I arrived to hospital I stayed here for a while and got taken to the ward. The staff on this ward have all been very polite, they have took the time to chat with me which has made me feel comfortable. I have a good bit of privacy on the ward and a lot of room to myself. The foods been nice, its always hot and there are some great meals on the menu. I don't think any improvements need to be made to the care the staff provided, they should just keep up the good work.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamhh1
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The girls are remarkable
body: The gynae ward is lovely, all the girls are remarkable. The care is just great, I have been really well cared for here during my stay. Everyone is very friendly and bubbly. I cant say I have had any issues at all. My room is great, i am grateful to have a side room. Cleanliness is fabulous, my room is always kept in shape.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Kmag
title: Nothing was ever too much hassle
body: Couldn’t be more grateful for the kindness and person centred care provided by Banbridge community midwives once I returned home from hospital after my C section delivery of my baby boy. Diane in particular is a credit to the team, never in a rush and always willing to listen and offer advice, nothing was ever too much hassle and always very reassuring . Means a lot during a difficult time so thank you very much!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: GP appointment
body: In the last 6 weeks my Wife, My Daughter and I have all needed appointments at the surgery. We have telephoned the surgery in the morning and received appointments on the same day of calling. We think this is an excellent service.

author: Niamhh1
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Very pleased with everything
body:
I am very pleased with everything on the ward. I think the staff are really good, everyone has been supportive and empathetic.  
The food is alright, the variety is standard enough but I would say they have more on the menu than I thought they would.  
Communication with staff has been okay, facilities are good and cleanliness is outstanding.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Outpatients staff do not lose interest
body:
Outpatients is okay, it is just a plain waiting room. The waiting room and the exam room are always clean and the white is always sparkling.  
What makes outpatients is the staff, they are great. The staff talk to you and seem interested throughout the whole thing, whereas some professionals will just act uninterested. The reception staff always have a smile on their face.  
Outpatients staff do not lose interest.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Decde74
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Everything has been great so far
body:
I arrived here last Sunday via the emergency department, I was waiting for around 5 hours before I got seen to by a doctor and brought up to the ward.  
Everything has been great so far it really has been a very good stay, I am due to be discharged later today after I get a few test results back.  
The staff are really good, the communication is also good. The facilities are very good and the food on offer is great too.  
I have no complaints regarding the hospital.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Outpatients has a calm and relaxing atmosphere
body:
Outpatients has been always good to me. I do not mind coming in and it literally being and in and out appointment since the staff have always been lovely. The department is clean and hygienic.  
The staff are lovely and have the craic with me. I get on with everyone since they are all so nice. I think it is the staff that make the atmosphere good in outpatients.  
Outpatients has a calm and relaxing atmosphere.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Stardrop
title: Unpleasant environment to work in
body:
I had to attend the Wishaw General Breast clinic where I saw a lovely well mannered Dr called Dr Mc Bain. Whilst waiting to see Dr McBain I could hardly breath because of the stuffiness of the room. The heating was awful, I was sweating like mad. I thought to myself those poor nurses and Dr’s are subjected to work in this environment everyday it shocking.  
I feel that NHS Lanarkshire should do something immediately as the rooms are awful to sit in. Thank God I couldn’t ask for a better, nicer Doctor - she was lovely as were all the nurse but to have to work in these conditions is shocking.

author: ophiuchusct93
title: Fantastic staff
body: I attend the breast screening clinic in May and June. Every single one of the staff: cleaner, nurses, doctors, surgeons were all so fantastic with the way I was treated. I go back in 2 weeks time for results and they have given me even more confidence in the way I will be treated for my aftercare. So a very big thank you to all involved.

author: Nusancepatiant
title: My experience of being admitted to Lincoln county hospital
body:
I’ve had chest pains on & off for sometime, I tried to get to see my own GP but due to the announcement on the recorded message ( we have a staff shortage at this time please try later) I tried later and on the following day to no avail. On the Wednesday I felt worse with stronger chest pains, at which point I phoned 111 and explained my symptoms, I was told to rest and they would send an ambulance which arrived within 15 minutes. I was fully examined and told I would need to go to hospital, excellent service. The downfall came as my previous text comments when I arrived at Lincoln A&E.  
Once I arrived on the short stay cardiac ward things improved dramatically with the excellent care by all the nurses on the ward. I was improving up until Friday when I had another very severe chest pains once again the nurses gave excellent care and did so all the following week. My worst experience was total lack of sleep by all the noise from other sick patients shouting out in the night to some of the night nurses talking loudly.  
Overall an experience I would not like to have again, as once they have you it’s a job to escape, it takes hours to get in and hours to get out, but thankfully I’m still alive to tell the tale, so a big thank you to all concerned look forward to my further recovery at home.

author: Brora Boy
title: My colonoscopy at Victoria Hospital
body:
From the time I entered the hospital to the time I left I was in the hands of people who cared and were also knowledgeable of what I was about to go through.  
The doctors and staff were so diligent in getting the right result for me.  
Their patience was to the extreme in completing this process and my dignity was never compromised.  
I very much appreciated their professionalism in dealing with me and I offer my heartfelt thanks to them all.

author: orangehx56
title: I bless the day I met her
body:
When I first met Judy in May, my husband had been admitted to Galloway Hospital the day before. I was very upset as he had just been diagnosed with Dementia, and that had floored me, as it's always been the two of us for the past 56 years and we were never blessed with a family. Judy sat there with her arms round me and let me talk all about it. She was so comforting, I don't know how I would have got through without her friendly smile and help.  
I had another meeting yesterday regarding what the possibilities were when my husband would be discharged. She let me have my say - what I thought at the time was a good plan, but Judy had made other enquiries and when I finished she then told me, at this moment in time, it wasn't feasible to take him home as I thought. He needed 24 hour care at that moment and I couldn't cope with that. What she told me made sense and I bless the day when I met her.  
She has been so kind, informative, and most of all, a most understanding person I have met since my husband took ill nearly 4 years ago. God Bless you Judy and THANK YOU.

author: membergb87
title: Seeing a physio
body: I had been referred to see a physio within my doctors surgery. He was so helpful and understanding, gave me a lot of advice and support.

author: faizw76
title: OT support
body:
My husband has Parkinson's and had a stroke, lost use of right arm. I have looked after him for 9 years but as things got worse was looking for years to make things easy for both him and myself. I have got anything I thought would help myself and have changed all shirt buttons to magnets and all shoes to to hook & loop, cutlery, ect. I also upgraded the bathroom with shower and raised toilet just needed some easy way to handle showering etc. LR was very nice and tried to help but think I have covered everything.  
It's more core help I need and was told that could take another year so still struggling on.

readBy.name: Office of Annabelle Ewing, MSP for Cowdenbeath

author: Sonjap
title: He went that extra mile
body:
Following the removal of a benign tumour in my neck I was admitted into Ward 12 for a 2 week stay. I was shortly introduced to Paul (Health Care Assistant) on one of his night shifts. Initially I felt apprehensive about having a male carer due to being female and in a somewhat vulnerable state. I was immediately at ease when Paul introduced himself and was more than willing to offer any support that he could.  
I really feel Paul went that extra mile with me. I would awake every morning to towels on my bed and the bathroom equipped for me to freshen up. Unfortunately I was hit with my menstrual cycle however I quickly realised this was nothing to be embarrassed about as Paul dealt with this discreetly and in his stride.  
Paul made the whole hospital stay much more comfortable for me. The shifts that Paul was present seemed to be more manageable and I often found myself hoping he would be on shift.  
I spent 2 weeks on this ward and cannot thank Paul enough for all of his care and attention. I am now home and recovering well.

author: ariesnc94
title: Great Carers
body: Our experience of the care we got was really good. No complaints at all. Carers were great and our Mental Health Nurse was a brilliant help. I will miss her.

readBy.name: East Ayrshire Health and Social Care Partnership

title: Absolutely amazing.
body:
Went in for complex cancer surgery.  Was put at ease at every turn.
Ended up staying for 6 weeks.  Every single person there I found to be professional and very caring.  From the surgeons to the domestics.  Every one of them went out of their way to make my stay as comfortable as possible.  I walked in the hospital with cancer and walked out without.  Thanks to each and every one of you involved.
Just goes to show that not all angels have wings.

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

author: hsmith970
title: Day Surgery CAH 4S
body:
I was admitted to 4 South for a day procedure. I was a bit anxious as would most people. I was assessed on arrival by Deputy Sister Bronagh and SHCSW Teresa. Immediately they put me at ease and explained how the day would go. The ward itself was clean and comfortable. I then met the anaesthetist (can't remember his name). He was fantastic with his explanation and my concerns around the general anaesthetic dissolved. He was very friendly and approachable. The Surgeon (Dr McCracken) then met with me and again he was brilliant. I was first on the list being an insulin dependent diabetic and again the team addressed my worries about my blood sugar levels. The entire theatre team were amazing, I only remember coming around in recovery. I was promptly returned to the ward (I wanted this so I could get dressed) and back under the care of Bronagh and Teresa. I was then given lunch which was very tasty and allowed to get up to mobilise.  
My entire experience from start to finish was excellent, the management of Ward 4 South and Theatres should be incredibly proud of their team. Thank you all so much. Hopefully I won't see you again (in the nicest possible way). You all are an asset to the NHS. Best wishes to you all.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Rosiepuppins
title: Let down by Forth Valley ENT
body:
Several years ago, I was referred to ENT for repeated ear infections. They found there was a seemingly permanent hole in my eardrum, as it had burst multiple times when I was young. The discomfort has carried on for around seven years since bursting the first time.  
After my last appointment in December 2021 (after almost an 18 month wait) where I found out there was still a hole in my eardrum, I was told I'd be seen again in June of the next year. I have only recently received a letter of my next appointment being July 2023. Over 18 months later again.  
Less than two weeks after getting my appointment letter I have been told this appointment has been cancelled by Forth Valley ENT. I feel let down and not taken seriously, as I've dealt with ear pain for years. This has prevented me from learning to swim, a skill that could be the difference between life and death, as water in my ear causes pain. I am more sensitive to water in my ear, temperature, and volume.  
I have had to sit out of outdoor P.E. lessons in the winter due to the cold causing discomfort in my ear, which is affecting my education. Family outings have had to be cut short if earmuffs are forgotten, which is disappointing and overall a pain to have to deal with.  
I feel all of this could have been resolved by now if the appointments had been made a priority. The inability to swim and the discomfort in the cold has made me unable to do certain things with friends and family, as well as being quite an embarrassing thing to have to admit. I hope it is resolved soon, and I do not have to deal with the disappointment of an appointment being cancelled again, as this has happened more times than appointments have gone forward at this point.

author: apusfn53
title: Accessing the community respiratory service
body:
I’d like to share feedback about accessing the community respiratory service from Southern health and social care trust. It was based ad Cecil Street in Newry. I found it very helpful, I’m in my eighties and I don’t go out much and they take me out. They seemed very nice.  
First of all it was good to have a place to go once a week, taking me out and I could go there and do a wee bit of shopping and come home, and the girls were very nice and they were monitoring me to make sure it wasn’t taking too much out of me when I was doing exercises. It’s finished now but it was every Thursday, it was a 6-8 week course. I am very thankful for it, it did help my breathing and they taught me a couple of wee things like how to come overcome the shortness of breath.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: watergb65
title: Bilateral knee replacement
body: I was very worried about the operation but as soon as I reached the Jubilee ward all the nurses made me feel a lot more relaxed Just too say a big thankyou to the surgeons, anaesthetics team, all the ☺️ nurse's and the very special lady that gave me those wonderful meals. Big thankyou.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great practice
body: Phoned one day, booked a phone appointment the next morning and saw the doctor the same day.  Very efficient and helpful.  Thank you.

author: HG99
title: Amazing support
body:
Lauren health visitor for Arbroath has been amazing in these last 6 months. With my first child because I was on the young side I had a Family Nurse instead where as this time around it was just Midwives and Health Visitor.  
Lauren is always happy, bubbly, and full of smiles before she even steps foot in the house and that just sets the visit off to such a good start. I know sometimes you can feel like a burden but Lauren is the complete opposite.  
Constantly telling me I’ve done amazing with breast feeding. Reassuring me when I didn’t realise I needed it. Lauren best interests are you and baby. Even little comments regarding a house smelling lovely went a long way. As house gets neglected after a baby sometimes.  
I’m gutted my journey with Lauren has come to an end. But I wish her all the best and thank you for being an amazing support. You truly are amazing and whoever gets you next is very lucky.

author: CJLHelensburgh
title: X-ray and CT scans - Vale of Leven Hospital, Alexandria
body:
I received an appointment for a chest X-ray that I wouldn't have been able to attend due to holiday commitments. The hospital re-arranged my appointment for today following a quick call. After that call, I received another appointment for a CT scan (also for when I was away).  
Instead of calling, I took that letter in and discussed it with the lady at the X-ray reception desk.  
The lady (my apologies - I didn't note her name) sorted a CT scan for me straight after my X-ray.  
Personally speaking, I thought it was brilliant, as were all the staff doing both scans. All friendly and all helpful.  
I really appreciated everything that was done today, brilliant hospital with brilliant staff.

author: POSITIVEVIBES
title: Coil Fitting Service
body: Wonderful Doctors, Nurses, and Receptionist staff. They were so good at making me feel at ease and really looked after me. Very grateful for their care and expertise. Thank you all.

author: Kutu21
title: Poor maternity experience
body:
I am writing this message about my experience with Liverpool women hospitals midwives - the ones that take care of the baby and mom on their first days together. I had a really had a bad experience with them one morning in June and with the night shift staff.  
It is my first time being a mom and my first time breastfeeding. I had one midwife who came to me at night on Thursday because my baby was crying so much and I don’t know how to calm him down. They took my baby off me in a way I didn't like and shouted at me that I was breastfeeding in wrong position, suggesting that I didn’t understand English.  
That made me so sad and I really was so tired because I hadn’t slept from the day I give birth as the other midwives when I asked for pain relief didn't come back for up to 2 hours. Also they were so rude with my husband, telling him we will not open the door for you if you go outside even for toilet but he needs to stay with me. We have no family here and I am so tired, that was really rude and a shame.  
I will never forget what happened for me in my last day in hospital and first time as mom.

author: Thurrock RC student
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Communicating with Confidence Course
body: I would highly recommend this course to my family, friends or work colleagues. My knowledge before the course was 1 out of 10, but after 4 weeks I felt a confident knowledge of 8 out of 10. I learned new techniques to help with my confidence, my communication in specific settings and my well-being. It reminded me of the strengths I have and how I can use these more. I also really enjoyed the course. Renée, Gina and Emma made it enjoyable and relatable. The group was small and friendly. It was not overpowering. I shall be signing up for more Recovery College in future, starting with My Rested Self: Relaxation. Thanks everyone!

author: Faijb74
title: About my brothers care
body:
I am writing ✍️ to thank Cornhill hospital 🏥 Huntly ward.  
I 🌈 have to compliment the staff of the Huntly ward for my brother's excellent care. A big thank you to Chris , Stef ,Daniel and Fae who does the nightshift  
Also the wonderful Fiona on the front reception of the building & Davie the porter.  
What a wonderful job they are doing in supporting the NHS & clients & Family providing excellent service. 👏  
Well done NHS Grampian please could you reward the staff members many blessings 🙌 💙🏥

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Thurrock RC student
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Confidence course
body:
I have just completed 4 weeks of the Communicating with Confidence course with the Recovery College.

I learnt that I am not the only one struggling. I know how to work things out, to be more assertive and believe in myself.

The course worked at the right pace for my learning and the teaching style suited my learning. I enjoyed the course and found it useful. I would be extremely likely to recommend this course to someone esle.

title: Improving practice
body: Don't get me wrong, I have criticised this practice when things have not been good.  But I have to say the last two appointments I have had have been 100%. The phone system which has been trying to say the least seems to gave improved,  I have got through and received an appointment. The doctor I saw on both occasions was really goog. I hope this improvement continues.

title: First rate
body: Another first rate appointment with nurse...prompt and professional with that lovely humour that this practice excels at.

title: A&E staff compliment
body:
My husband seemed to be suffering from
Adrenal insufficiency, though we were not aware.  The staff were rushed off their feet but they didn’t act harassed or rush us.  They did their very best, with kindness and a smile.  
We both thank you so much and want you all to know that you are valued & respected.  Your work and personal sacrifice is appreciated beyond measure.,  
Our best wishes and kindest regards 
Sue & Alton Johnson

title: First class treatment
body:
I consulted the practice, minimal waiting time, follow up minor op very quickly conducted, efficiently and excellent aftercare
Total confidence 
Relieved and most grateful to all the staff at Plowright

title: Fantastic caring service
body: Always kind caring and understanding . Very very helpful with things well explained. Never too long to wait when arriving at the surgery the whole experience is a credit to the doctors and staff at mark street and the NHS in general. Long may it continue .

author: Thurrock RC student
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Communicating with Confidence course
body:
This course used different ways of learning which I really liked. It was dynamic and I liked the changes made. It definitely really helped me to learn at my own pace. I found it moved to different subjects (I liked how much was covered). The things I learnt, I know I will use. The course really covered a lot of different areas of the subjects. It met the aims as I could think about lots of related things.

I would really recommend this course to anyone else.

title: My elderly mothers care.
body: My elderly mother was recently hospitalised with sepsis, and as a family we cannot praise the care she received at Blackpool Victoria  Hospital. Within 20mins of arriving at a very busy A&E, she was given antibiotics which continued throughout the night. She was transferred to a ward, which was very busy, but she once again received wonderful care and was treated with respect throughout. The consultant and staff kept the family up to date with her ongoing care, and when it was clear she was not going to recover, we were given choices of where she should receive palliative care and several agencies were involved in this process,  but we were kept informed throughout. Thank you once again to all the staff who came into contact with mum.

readBy.name: Blackpool Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Was a great practice
body: This practice has no Doctor since he went on sabbatical two years ago and now is not coming back. His patients have been sent to other clinics well out of the local area including me who is 75 years of age. I had been with the surgery for about forty years. So unfair.

title: All so kind
body:
I was transferred from a.e to the a.c.u the level of care was the best. Was looked after and informed every step of the way, had many tests, and things booked going forward. From the minute I walked in and spoke to the secretary to the minute I left, it was all a positive experience. 
Thank you all the staff for looking after me your kind and caring got me through

title: Very Good Practice
body: I like to stay always with Saddlers Health Centre because they are friendly and they are professionals with very good doctors.

author: Madge51
title: I was told there was no trace of my request
body:
For a number of weeks I've been ringing the Respiratory Lab at Wishaw General to ask if I could go on the cancellation list for a Lung Function Test.  
This is one of 3 mandatory test that Systemic Sclerosis patient should have annually. I was told on multiple dates that there was no trace of the request.  
On all these occasions I thought I was speaking with the same staff member, but later this staff member denied any prior knowledge of my enquiry. They told me that they were working on it right then & would call me back. I got no call back, but when I rang nearly a week later, low & behold the request is there & has been BACKDATED 5 weeks.  
If a mistake is made there's no shame in saying so, apologise & move on but to change the details of what happened, that's unforgivable. My experiences with Rheumatology at Wishaw over the last 18 months have been horrendous & hugely damaging to my mental health. I feel irrelevant & worthless & have had to seek help from Samaritans. I need this treatment to stop, it's doing harm.

title: Compassionate understanding
body: 111 called ambulance. The medical Team were caring and thorough and made me feel at ease. I was not treated as a number and time was given to make sure I was alright. This was also true at Worthing hospital. The nurses and the doctor who diagnosed me were considerate and humanwhen they might have even officious given the pressures they are under. Such a profoundly worthwhile profession to have chosen and my thanks go to all.

author: blackbirdhz38
title: Deteriorating support and increased pressure on carers
body:
Service provision and support for carers used to be something NHS Tayside and in particular Glenlaw house and Kingspark school medical unit prided themselves on, until Covid happened.  
Despite having open access to the ward we are constantly being told we must go through A&E which is more crowded and has a high risk of cross infection of our exceptional complex needs children and told by A&E that we have to go to the ward, without any examination. This wastes our time and the time of the over worked staff within A&E and ambulance staff, not to mention money wasted going from one area to the other.  
Within respite we now have to fill out more forms every time our children have respite, this includes medication forms for the medication our children are on which the unit all ready have access to on the NHS system.  
Every consultation carried out on behalf of carers states, form filling is one of the most disliked and time consuming things carers have to do and should be reduced not increased.  
We are also being told we must date medication when we open it, this is practice used on stock medication not prescribed as the quantity given, is to be used before new prescription can be made. (Order made 1 week before you run out).  
Now the school has changed to using stock emergency seizure medication, after 10+ years they can no longer keep stock supply, which due to the amount of emergency medication my child can have in one week and the time it can take to obtain from prescription, leaves my child with the high risk of not having any emergency meds at school. I have had to withdraw my child and keep them at home.  
Each one of these changes were made without any consultation with carers which breaches NHS Taysides own policies.  
Either bureaucracy has over taken common sense or carers are now doing the job of the nurses free of charge but full of the stress that they really do not need and it is not acceptable.  
I would have preferred to write a more positive story but these issues are being ignored and children with exceptional complex medical needs are suffering from having exhausted carers falling into ill health from these practices.

title: Caring Staff
body: Needed to wait for bed but the treatment I received from the ambulance medics & hospital staff were caring. Broke hip after tripping at home . Would like to thank nurses working in Ridge ward & the medical team for taking care of me before & after hip replacement.  All well now . Thank you

author: GlasgowMama
title: Maternity services
body:
I had quite a complicated situation with lots of different health factors to consider and I cannot fault the care and attention I was given at an exciting but uncertain time. The midwives, consults, nurses and the paediatric team were all fantastic, kind and did their utmost to provide the best care and information possible.  
Afte 2 miscarriages and a bleed in this pregnancy at 11 weeks I was diagnosed with Melanoma at 36 weeks pregnant. I was unable to have treatment while pregnant and was also informed this could affect the baby. Everyone I encountered at (numerous!) appointments were informed about my situation and were incredibly kind, empathic and understanding, reassuring me as much as their knowledge would allow. There were so many different teams involved but they all communicated well and this continued after my baby arrived to ensure we all had the correct and best follow up care possible.  
Thanks to everyone involved from midwives, consultants, secretaries and nurses across paediatrics, plastic surgery, dermatology, oncology and obstetrics a terrifying time was made as reassuring as possible and my little boy and I got the all clear 7 weeks after his birth.  
I cannot be more grateful for the staff and care in NHS GGC

readBy.name: MASScot- Melanoma Action and Support Scotland

title: Refreshing
body: To be honest when I went to the surgery recently as a new patient for my annual review, I realised how lucky we are as patients to be able to come to a surgery to have care treatment. As a new patient I didn't know what to expect, on how I would be treated when I first went a few months ago now, and found that there was nothing to be worried about. I've attended the surgery a few times now, and on each occasion I have found the staff to be very welcoming and friendly. It's refreshing to know through these troubled times that help is there, and surgery members do care.

title: Excellent fast response
body: I called the practice this morning and was given an appointment at 10:20. The doctor was thorough, very friendly and listened well to what I explained. She gave me a diagnosis and some treatment. I was very pleased with the whole experience and the speed of response of the practice.

title: Great staff very caring
body: Just had a vasectomy and was worried I also have other problems which the team handled perfectly during my time here they made me feel safe and comfortable. Which is fantastic as I am a very unstable patient  thank you

author: Aalcyon
title: Going the extra mile
body:
I had been on a waiting list for an abdominal hernia operation, for various reasons, for almost nine years.  
Unfortunately when I finally received a date for surgery I had other medical issues. I had been suffering for over a month from what bore all the hallmarks of a quite disabling Rheumatoid Arthritis flare-up and had been waiting two weeks for as GP appointment to progress to a Rheumatologist Consultant consultation The GP was excellent (thank you Dr Lennox) and in light of the long waiting times for a Rheumatologist Consultant appointment was prepared to treat my symptoms with an intra-muscular steroid injection but only if the surgical team Anesthetist gave the "green light". It was the week before the surgery date but as luck would have it, I had a pre-op assessment team that afternoon.The pre-op assessment team were excellent. Also when I explained the GP conditional treatment offer to them Nurse Charlene offered to make contact with the surgical team to inquire if the intra-muscular steroid injection so close to surgery would be OK. In view of the time-crunch, and the state of me, she stated that she would try to get an answer the following day.  
Before 10:00 am the next morning nurse Charlene confirmed that the surgical team had given the OK for the intra-muscular steroid injection. By lunch-time the GP surgery had confirmed a GP nurses station appointment for the injection. Within two days, that injection made made such a difference to the use of my hands, flexibility and my overall mobility.  
I am very grateful to all involved.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Irresponsible time frame
body: Been waiting for over an hour regardless of the appointment time with a 2 year old poor service patient who came after us were seen and left

readBy.name: Sandwell and West Birmingham Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Superb care service
body:
I took my son to village surgery for an emergency appointment yesterday afternoon. Both reception and the paramedic we saw were so welcoming, and we were seen so quickly. The paramedic was thorough, extremely friendly, attentive to what we said and extremely helpful.
You were fantastic. Well done Village surgery.

title: Great practice and fantastic reception
body: I had an experience today that is unparalleled. I have been having issues with getting my repeat prescription from moving from one surgery to Elizabeth Court Surgery. I went down to the Surgery and explained the issues I had experienced and it had been incredibly difficult as it was related to mental health. The reception, especially one particular individual,  was absolutely amazing and really came to my rescue, I mean that quite literally. I am very grateful to the extremely compassionate and professional staff in resolving my matter today and would recommend the expert services of Elizabeth Courtauld Surgery any day. Thank you so much for helping me through this difficult time.

title: Woeful
body: Letter sent from CHEC contained no information so no idea which condition this was for (son has already had two separate appointments at the local NHS hospital and been signed off by one consultant so this one may be unnecessary). The telephone number on the letter didn’t work but had spent 3 days trying to get through. Eventually tracked down a chat service online and was told the number was wrong and changed in May - but our letter was dated June! If I hadn’t persevered would have had to decide to attend appointment and lose day’s pay or be a no show. Really worried for our NHS if this is the solution…

author: scoreboardmx48
title: Cancer service
body: Out friend from school is in the Beatson. He has been diagnosed with terminal cancer. We have been happy with the service provided.

author: annmk64
title: Exceptional care for Ectopic Pregnancy
body:
I came in to A&E with severe cramping following a suspected miscarriage or ectopic pregnancy. The care I received from the staff at RAH was exceptional. I was treated with immense kindness and dignity by the two consultants who attended to me and the staff nurses who went above and beyond to make me comfortable and make what was a bad experience bearable.  
Dr Yu-Ting (apologies for getting the name misspelt), Kirsty, Beth, Claire, Dorca, Wendy, Kayleigh, Linda were all fabulous in making sure everything was okay, and genuinely, as bad as my personal situation was in this case, every single staff member without exception could not have been better.  
If I have missed out any names, that was just my memory — I will always be grateful for the treatment I received on ward 32 at the RAH.  
Absolute gems.

author: Christophervc23
title: Nothing is a problem for them.
body: My uncle is being looked after by the Kilbryde hospice. The staff are worth their weight in gold. They are very attentive and nothing is a problem for them. The reception staff and nursing staff are very welcoming and are definitely the right people for the job.

author: scorpiustx46
title: Made to feel comfortable
body: My friend from school has a brain tumour and is in end of life care. We have felt welcomed and supported and made to feel comfortable and he is being looked after well.

author: KMcQ
title: Physio Appointment
body:
[Very happy with 'Future plans']  
  
Great service provided by the Physiotherapist Adam. Thorough history taken and comprehensive examination. Diagnosis and treatment plan/physio exercises explained really well and written material given to take home. I really felt well looked after and cared for and best treatment given. Thank you very much Adam, for the great service you gave me this morning.  
[Very happy with 'Staff attitude']

author: lbre
title: Day Procedure Unit, Omagh Hospital
body:
I had an extremely positive experience today when attending the day procedure unit in Omagh hospital to have nerve block treatment to my knee.  
All of the staff were extremely helpful, caring, professional , thoughtful and talked me through every step of the process.  
I felt very reassured regarding my treatment and aftercare.  
Many thanks to all the staff.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: A very happy mummy
title: Very impressed with the service
body:
I took my child to the minor injuries unit recently with a possible fracture.  
We were seen straight away, assessed and sent for an x-ray. Walked straight in to x-ray and was reviewed within ten minutes of returning to the minor injuries unit. I just want to say thank you to the amazing receptionist, nurses and radiographer for making this a very fast process and for being so amazing with my child to keep her calm and not overwhelmed.  
I was dreading taking her to the hospital as I understand the strain the NHS is under.  
You are doing an amazing job and I really appreciate all that you do.  
Thank you.

author: Kcarstven70
title: Paediatric staff going above and beyond
body:
In June I called PAU at 9:30pm as my daughter had abdominal pain on right hand side, explained that my daughter had a congenital adrenal hyperplasia and that we were just at A&E the Wednesday before with the same thing and they just sent us home. With no hesitation they told us to come through and they would look at her.  
We arrived at 10.50pm and the doctors were so quick to examine my daughter and then discovered that the pain was possible coming from her ovaries. The staff doctors both doctors on duty were called Laura they said your daughter will be going through to ward 29 and will be going for an ultrasound in the morning @ 10:45am.  
We moved to ward 29 and the staff were amazing, making sure that my daughter wasn’t in pain and they kept asking if she was ok as they noticed that she was suffering. Later on the gynaecologist came in and said that your daughter has to get surgery as she has cysts on her right ovary which was 9cm and they were concerned so my daughter went for emergency surgery. They were fantastic with my daughter and explained everything what they were going to do, which put my daughter at ease. All the staff in the theatre were amazing also having a laugh singing to Taylor Swift .  
13 days later my daughter was concerned about her stitches so I called ward 30 in the morning they said we’ll have a look for you. The staff, Kelly and her colleagues, were so friendly and looked at my daughters stitches. They trimmed off the tails of her stitches as one of them was slightly embedded into her bellybutton which was causing it to be sore and uncomfortable. They were so professional and talked there way through every step with my daughter. In all ward 29, pau, gynaecology and ward 30 went above and beyond to help my daughter. 🤩🤩  
Can’t say the same for A&E. If this had been noticed on the Wednesday it could have been resolved before the Tuesday the following week .

title: Great doctor
body: The GP was excellent but making an appointment can be difficult , unable to get through on the telephone

author: Disgusted sane patient
title: Lack of stroke care
body:
My MRI results got lost then sent to a unknown doctor that nobody has ever heard of. Fairfield general won't discuss my results with me and said they are “too busy” and I need to stop being anxious and more understanding that they are very busy.  
I have now decided not to get these results and live my life however long I have left.

author: Alimm34
title: I would be happy to be a patient in ward 10C.
body:
Attended A&E at the QEUH recently. Within 40 minutes I saw a triage nurse who immediately called a doctor. I had blisters on my hands which were joining up and 1 hand was swollen. Immediately hooked up to an Antibiotic IV drip, had blood taken. Saw an Orthopaedic surgeon who advised that I needed to be admitted. Thereafter I was sent for X-rays on my swollen hand before being admitted to ward 10C.  
From being given tea and a sandwich (hadn’t eaten since 1pm) shortly after admission to being discharged 4 days later I was provided with exemplary care and dignity by the whole team. A special thanks goes to Nurse Feeney whose calm and reassuring manner helped alleviate any concerns I had. You are a star. I left hospital full of admiration for all the staff at the hospital who work so well together for the benefit of patients. I am currently on the waiting list for hip replacement surgery and I would be happy to be a patient in ward 10C.

author: Roxburghe house
title: Spending quality time together as a family.
body:
As a family we were all nervous coming to Roxburghe house. There was no reason to be. We can't thank the staff enough, we felt listened to and all of our questions answered.  
The environment was so peaceful and allowed us to spend quality time together as a family. Thank you to the doctors, nurses, domestics and the entire team, you are such special people and should be so proud of the hard work and dedication you show every day. It doesn't go unnoticed, we can't thank you enough.  
Special thank you to Laurie for the kindness, laughs and care, we never felt alone with you by our side.  
Thank you all.

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership
